p: Water-in-oil (W/O) heterogeneous gelation involves the emulsification step of aqueous droplets of the protein (gelling agent) stably dispersed in a continuous organic phase with the aid of oil-soluble surfactants [ 73]. This method is used to better control the size of particles. The proteins within the water droplets of the W/O emulsion are then cross-linked using enzymes [ 74], thermal denaturation [ 75] UV-light induced cross-linking [ 76], or addition of cross-linking ions [ 77]. The general methods for W/O heterogeneous gelation include inverse (mini)emulsion, the reverse micellar method, and membrane emulsification, and a brief explanation is presented below [ 78].
